content.user_title: Create charts and data visualizations with Python
content.value_statement: Communicating data insights visually requires choosing the right chart type and mastering multiple libraries. This skill guides you through creating professional visualizations using matplotlib, seaborn, plotly, and altair.
actual_capabilities: Generate line charts, bar charts, pie charts, scatter plots, histograms, and heatmaps
Create visualizations using matplotlib, seaborn, plotly, and altair libraries
Build multi-axis plots and subplot grids for complex datasets
Apply custom themes, annotations, and styling to charts
Export visualizations to PNG, SVG, and PDF formats
limitations: Cannot access external databases or APIs directly
Generates code that must be executed locally by the user
Does not create real-time or streaming visualizations
Limited to code generation without interactive dashboard hosting

use_cases.title: Integrate charts into applications

prompt_templates.title: Simple line chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a matplotlib line chart showing monthly values with title, axis labels, and grid lines.

prompt_templates.title: Distribution histogram
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a seaborn histogram with KDE overlay showing the distribution of values. Include appropriate labels.

prompt_templates.title: Interactive scatter plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a plotly scatter plot with hover tooltips showing correlation between two variables. Enable zoom and pan.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-chart dashboard
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a matplotlib figure with four subplots: heatmap, bar chart, line chart, and box plot using consistent styling.

output_examples.input: Create a bar chart comparing quarterly revenue
output: Bar chart with quarters on x-axis
Revenue values on y-axis with currency labels
Color gradient from light to dark blue
Value labels displayed above each bar

output_examples.input: Show temperature distribution for the year
output: Histogram with 20 bins showing temperature frequency
KDE curve overlay for smooth distribution
X-axis labeled with temperature in Celsius

best_practices: Match chart type to your data structure and the insight you want to communicate
Include clear titles, axis labels, and legends for self-explanatory visualizations
anti_patterns: Using 3D effects for simple data comparisons which distorts perception
Including too many data series in one chart causing visual clutter
Omitting axis labels or units making charts difficult to interpret

faq.question: Which library should I use for my visualization?
faq.answer: Use matplotlib for static charts, seaborn for statistics, plotly for interactive web charts, and altair for declarative specifications.

faq.question: What export formats are available?
faq.answer: PNG for web images, SVG for scalable graphics, and PDF for print and publication-quality output.

faq.question: Can this skill connect to my database?
faq.answer: No. You provide data as input. The skill generates code that processes data you specify in your local environment.

faq.question: Is my data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: No. Your data stays local. The skill only generates Python code that runs on your machine.

faq.question: Why do I get code instead of an image?
faq.answer: The skill generates Python code you run locally. This gives you full control over dependencies and execution.

faq.question: Can I create animated charts?
faq.answer: Yes. Request matplotlib animations or plotly animated charts. The generated code will include animation frames.
